message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and family history suggest Tay-Sachs disease, which does not allow for the breakdown of GM2 ganglioside. Glucocerebroside accumulates in Gaucher disease, galactocerebroside in Krabbe disease, and ceramide trihexoside in Fabry disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest the patient has Tay-Sachs disease, which is associated with the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside in the brain and nervous system. The other options are associated with different lysosomal storage diseases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the patient’s Ashkenazi Jewish descent suggest Tay-Sachs disease. Tay-Sachs disease is caused by a deficiency of hexosaminidase A, leading to the accumulation of GM2 gangliosides. Therefore, the most likely metabolite to accumulate in this patient’s disease is GM2 ganglioside.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and familial background suggest Tay-Sachs disease, which is caused by a deficiency in hexosaminidase A enzyme leading to accumulation of GM2 ganglioside in neurons. Glucocerebroside accumulation is seen in Gaucher disease, galactocerebroside in Krabbe disease, and ceramide trihexoside in Fabry disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and fundoscopic findings suggest Tay-Sachs disease, which is caused by a deficiency in hexosaminidase A leading to accumulation of GM2 ganglioside. Glucocerebroside accumulation is seen in Gaucher disease, galactocerebroside accumulation is seen in Krabbe disease, and ceramide trihexoside accumulation is seen in Fabry disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and fundoscopy findings suggest that the most likely diagnosis is Tay-Sachs disease, which is caused by a deficiency in hexosaminidase A leading to the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside. Glucocerebroside accumulation is seen in Gaucher disease, galactocerebroside accumulation is seen in Krabbe disease, and ceramide trihexoside accumulation is seen in Fabry disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and demographic information suggest that the patient may have Tay-Sachs disease, which is caused by a deficiency in hexosaminidase A enzyme leading to accumulation of GM2 ganglioside in the brain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s clinical presentation suggests Tay-Sachs disease, which is most commonly seen in people of Ashkenazi Jewish descent. The bright red macular spots on fundoscopy suggest GM2 ganglioside accumulation. Glucocerebroside and galactocerebroside accumulation are seen in Gaucher disease and Krabbe disease, respectively. Ceramide trihexoside accumulation is seen in Fabry disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described are consistent with Tay-Sachs disease, which is common in Ashkenazi Jews. The bright red macular spots seen on fundoscopy are called cherry-red spots and are a hallmark of Tay-Sachs disease. The disease is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme hexosaminidase A, which leads to the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside in the brain and nervous system.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the patient's Ashkenazi Jewish descent suggest Tay-Sachs disease. Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disorder that results in the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside in the brain and other tissues. Glucocerebroside accumulation occurs in Gaucher disease, galactocerebroside accumulation occurs in Krabbe disease, and ceramide trihexoside accumulation occurs in Fabry disease.
